title: Davidvictorson
author: Davidvictorson
content: I stumbled on this interesting story on YouTube. Although it is from 6years ago, I guess that many people may not have known that it happened. Otto de Voogd is the world's self-proclaimed first bitcoin refugee. Why? Because about six (6) years ago, he fled Estonia for the Netherlands after being threatened with imprisonment for being a staunch bitcoin advocate and for running a bitcoin exchange BTC.ee. What actually happened was that at that time, the Estonian government wanted to regulate bitcoin trading and other digital currencies. Otto de Voogd's company BTC.ee was one of the crypto companies targeted by the Estonian Financial Intelligence Unit. His appeal to the Tallinn Administrative Court and the Tallinn Circuit Court to operate a bitcoin exchange which was turned down twice. He therefore, had no option than to flee the country or risk being imprisoned for 3 years. Indeed bitcoin has come a long way. Do you have a similar story to share?Source

comments.author: crwth
comments.body: This is, of course, the documented one; we will never know how many more people have been a refugee and uses Bitcoin as their source of funds. Imagine it being more than ten years ago in existence here, and the self-proclaimed one is not the first, IMO. It's going to be hard to verify, though.I think that's just the part where it's just gaining traction, and back then, countries are finding ways to regulate it. They just probably haven't found a solution yet at that time. No one wants jail time, for sure.

comments.author: Pmalek
comments.body: It's the first time I hear about this particular case. The site of the old Estonian exchange is still live, but it's no longer operational. The man moved to The Netherlands and started the same type of exchange there and called it CoinEra. https://coinera.eu/. That site is also still live but non-operational just like the Estonian version. He did write an announcement when he closed it down mentioning he never experienced the issues from Estonia in the Netherlands.Interesting case. Estonia has lately often been tagged as one of the most crypto-friendly nations in the world. Looks like that wasn't always the case. Probably the root problem was that the government wanted to tax the traders but Otto didn't make it easy for them.   BTW, your newsbtc source is unavailable.

Do you have a similar story to share?SourceThere must be other stories available but I have one to share. But in my store I won't use the word "Refugee". Zebpay was the first ever bitcoin wallet and exchange service available in India. They were doing business when there was no rules and regulations available for cryptocurrency in India. So as expected, Indian government started attacks through the banks and their bank accounts were frozen. The owner of Zebpay was a true visionary and he knew that if he tries to fight a legal battle in India, he will have to spend the rest of his life on this. So he simply moved to Singapore with some of his initial employees and registered his business there. Now he is operating in more than 30 countries excluding India. Can we call him a willful refugee??

comments.author: Upgrade00
comments.body: It's always ironic to me how governments can effectively try to clamp down on those linked to things that they do not support like Bitcoin, and how media channels can censor Bitcoin related terms, but various scams are run under these platforms constantly.It's unfortunate the guy had to flee his country, cause the government were not informed enough on how it works.Estonia seems to be a bit more friendly now to Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies than it was all those years ago.
